['Decay - The process of decaying or spoiling due to natural breakdown over time, often associated with food and organic matter.', 'Rancid - Describes an unpleasant smell and taste in food caused by oxidation of fats and oils.', 'Spoiled - Used as the past participle of "spoil" to describe something that has been ruined, damaged or no longer fresh due to neglect.', 'Fermented - A process where microorganisms break down food substances like sugar into alcohol and acids, often resulting in spoiled or off-flavored products if uncontrolled.', 'Putrid - Describes a foul smell produced by decaying organic matter; associated with the strong odor of spoiling food.', 'Decayed - Refers to something that has undergone deterioration or decomposition, often due to exposure and neglect.', 'Rancidified - The process in which fats become rancid due to oxidation, resulting in a bad taste and smell.', 'Corrupt - In the context of food spoilage, it refers to the deterioration or damage caused by improper handling or storage conditions.', 'Mouldy - Refers to something that has been contaminated with mold growth due to exposure to moisture and lack of proper preservation methods.', 'Moldy - Describes food, especially bread or cheese, which has become infested with mold, making it unsuitable for consumption.', 'Souring - A process where acids develop in food causing a sour taste and smell; often caused by bacterial growth.', 'Forgone - Describes something that is no longer usable or relevant due to being overtaken by time, similar to the spoilage of perishable items if not consumed in a timely manner.', 'Decrepit - Refers to a state of disrepair and deterioration often used metapomedically, but it can also apply to objects or buildings that have been neglected over time.', 'Saturated - In the context of spoilage, this word could refer to foods rich in fats or oils which are more susceptible to rancidity if not properly stored.', "Off-putting - Something that is unappetizing or repulsive due to its state of spoiling; it can also be used more broadly for situations, people or things that deter one's interest or desire.", 'Fermented - Refers to the process in which microorganisms break down food substances like sugar into alcohol and acids, often leading to a change in taste and smell if not controlled properly; can result in spoilage.', 'Overripe - Describes fruits or vegetables that have been allowed to ripen for too long causing them to become soft, mushy, and unpalatable.', 'Mutilated - In the context of food spoilage, it refers to an item being ruined due to damage or negligence in its handling; can be applied more broadly as well.', 'Unappealing - Describes something that lacks attractiveness or interest, often caused by a state of spoilage making it undesirable for consumption.', 'Spoiling - The process through which food or other perishable items become unsuitable for use due to natural breakdown, bacterial growth or oxidation over time.']

['Nurturer - someone who cares for and tends to others, often a role taken by a nurturing female figure in healing contexts.', 'Mediator - a person who intervenes between parties to resolve disputes or issues, which can involve emotional healing as well.', 'Comforter - an individual known for providing solace and relief during times of distress or illness, typically associated with female figures.', 'Caregiver - someone responsible for attending to the needs of others, particularly in health-related situations; commonly a role filled by women.', 'Alchemist (historical) - an individual who sought to turn base metals into gold and pursued healing knowledge; although not exclusive to females, some historical female alchemists were notable figures.', 'Healer - broad term for someone engaged in the practice of medicine or restoration of health, can be gender-neutral but often refers to women in traditional practices.', "Nursemaid (historical) - a woman who looked after children's needs, which could involve comforting and caring during illnesses.", 'Herbalist - a practitioner using plants for medicinal purposes; many herbalists have been historically female figures in healing practices.', 'Soother - an individual known to calm others down or alleviate discomfort, often associated with maternal qualities.', 'Emissary - someone who sends out representatives on behalf of a group or organization; can relate to conveying messages for healing and wellness in communities.', 'Tender-hearted - describes a person who is naturally compassionate and sympathetic, often seen as nurturing traits associated with females when it comes to healing.', 'Angel (in spiritual context) - celestial beings believed to protect and offer comfort; in some beliefs, an angel can intervene for the healing of individuals.', 'Sage - a woman who is considered wise or learned in matters of health and well-being, often associated with traditional medicine.', "Whisperer - someone who uses soft, comforting words to provide solace; metaphorically can be seen as 'healing' through gentle communication.", 'Healer (folkloric) - a term sometimes used in folklore for mythical or supernatural figures believed to possess the power of healing, often female characters like witches and fairy godmothers.', 'Carer - someone who provides care and support, particularly in health-related contexts; women have been traditionally seen as primary carers.', "Nursemaid (childcare) - a woman who takes responsibility for children's welfinaspecially during illnesses or when parents are away.", 'Emissary of Healing - an individual or group representing the principles and practices of healing, often with women leading in compassionate roles.', 'Restorer (of health) - a person who works to restore physical well-being, which can be associated with female figures such as nurses or traditional midwives.', 'Guardian angel (spiritual/religious context) - supernatural entities believed to protect and provide for individuals; in some cultures, guardian angels are thought of as having a feminine aspect dedicated to healing.']

['Playwright - William Shakespeare was an influential English playwright and poet.', 'Sonnet - Many famous sonnets, such as "Sonnet 18," were written by Shakespeare.', 'Bard - A term often used to describe a skilled poet or storyteller like Shakespeare himself.', "Globe Theatre - The venue where many of Shakespeare's plays were performed during his lifetime.", 'Elizabethan Era - This period in English history, named after Queen Elizabeth I, is when Shakespeare wrote most of his work.', 'Sonneteer - A person who writes sonnets; often used to describe William Shakespeare.', 'Stratford-upon-Avon - The birthplace and hometown of Shakespeare where he was born in 1564.', 'Quarto - A type of book format that many early editions of Shakespeare\'s plays were published in, such as the "First Quarto" version of "Hamlet."', 'Verse - A form of writing that follows a specific metrical pattern and rhyme scheme; Shakespeare was known for his skillful use of verse.', 'Soliloquy - A dramatic device where a character speaks their thoughts aloud, typically used by Shakespeare in many of his plays.', 'Tragedy - One of the genres for which Shakespeare is most famous; he wrote several renowned tragedies such as "Romeo and Juliet" and "Macbeth."', 'Comedy - Another genre that William Shakespeare excelled at, with plays like "A Midsummer Night\'s Dream" and "Much Ado About Nothing."', 'Thespian - A term used to describe actors or people associated with the theatre; often linked to Shakespeare due to his influence on the craft.', 'Pound Alley - The narrow alley where the Globe Theatre was located, leading up to the main stage and entrance of the building.', "Folios - Collected editions of Shakespeare's plays that were published in large volumes after his death; including the famous First Folio compiled by John Heminges and Henry Condell.", 'Immortality - Many people believe that William Shakespeare achieved literary immortality with his enduring works still read, performed, and celebrated today.', 'Dramatic Archetypes - Several iconic characters created by Shakespeare, such as Hamlet, Othello, and Lady Macbeth, have become archetypal figures in literature and drama.', "Folger Library - A prestigious library that houses the First Folio of William Shakespeare's plays, among other significant collections related to his life and work.", 'Globe Literature - The body of literary works associated with the Globe Theatre and the Elizabethan era in which it was prominent; this includes not only Shakespeare but also contemporary playwrights like Christopher Marlowe and Ben Jonson.']
